quiz.title: Unit 7: Imperfect Competition (Quiz 7)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Mixed Practice: Monopoly & Monopolistic Competition
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Demand Elasticity, Price Discrimination, Long-Run Equilibrium, Profit Maximization

questions.question: If a monopolist is producing in the inelastic region of their demand curve, they will surely increase profit if they do which of the following?
options: Increase quantity and decrease price
Increase quantity and increase price
Decrease quantity and not change price
Decrease quantity and increase price
Decrease quantity and decrease price
questions.explanation: In the inelastic portion of demand (|Ed| < 1), marginal revenue is negative. Reducing quantity increases total revenue (since MR < 0 means TR rises as Q falls) and lowers total cost, thereby increasing profit. The monopolist will raise price along the demand curve as quantity decreases.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true for a perfectly price discriminating monopoly?
options: The firm profit maximizes at the quantity where marginal cost equals marginal revenue
The firm produces lower quantities than a single price monopoly
The firm sells different units of output for different prices
The firm is allocatively efficient when it produces the profit maximizing quantity
There will be no consumer surplus for the product
questions.explanation: Perfect price discrimination results in the monopolist producing the allocatively efficient quantity (where P = MC), which is greater than the single-price monopoly quantity. All other statements are true: it profit maximizes where MR = MC (with MR = demand), charges different prices, is allocatively efficient, and captures all consumer surplus as producer surplus.

questions.question: If a monopolistically competitive firm is earning economic profits in the short run, what will happen to the firm’s demand curve and quantity of output in the long run?
options: Demand will shift left and output will decrease
Demand will shift right and output will increase
Demand will shift left and output will increase
Demand will not change and output will decrease
Demand will shift right and output will not change
questions.explanation: Short-run economic profits attract new firms into the market, reducing each existing firm's market share. This causes each firm's demand curve to shift left (and become more elastic). In long-run equilibrium, output decreases, price falls, and economic profit returns to zero.

questions.question: Suppose Riaz’s Radios is a profit-maximizing monopolistically competitive firm in the radio market and is currently in long-run equilibrium. If Riaz’s Radios has an average total cost of $6, and a marginal cost of $6, which of the following is necessarily true?
options: Riaz’s Radios will decrease revenue if production is increased
Riaz’s Radios has inelastic demand at the profit-maximizing quantity
Riaz’s Radios has a price of $9
Riaz’s Radios has an average revenue of $8
Riaz’s Radios has a marginal revenue greater than $7
questions.explanation: In monopolistic competition, P > MR. Given MR = MC = $6 (profit-max condition), P must be > $6. Average Revenue (AR) equals price, so AR > $6. Among the options, only AR = $8 satisfies AR > $6. Also, MR positive means demand is elastic, not inelastic (B is false). Revenue increases if output rises when MR > 0 (A is false). Specific prices of $9 or MR > $7 are not guaranteed (C and E are false).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of monopoly elasticity, price discrimination, and monopolistic competition dynamics.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review the relationship between MR, P, and demand elasticity in different market structures.
scoreMessages.50: Needs work on profit maximization conditions, long-run adjustments, and price discrimination outcomes.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on core concepts: MR vs. P, long-run equilibrium in monopolistic competition, and perfect price discrimination.
